cert_history.note: Cross-cert: roblox-com.us SAN includes roblox-com.pl, linking both domains to same operator

forms.action_note: No action attribute — form submits to same page by default, but JavaScript in css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js likely intercepts the submit event to exfiltrate credentials

deceptive_buttons.actual_behavior: Dispatches submit event on login-form-real — harvests credentials instead of sending OTP
Dispatches submit event on login-form-real — harvests credentials instead of cross-device flow

exfiltration_endpoints.note: Obfuscated-name JS file loaded from css/ directory (directory masquerading). Not captured in urlscan DOM snapshot — this file likely contains the form submit handler that POSTs credentials to an attacker-controlled endpoint. The filename 'oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349' appears to be keyboard-mashed gibberish to avoid signature-based detection.

page_fidelity.angularjs_evidence: Duplicate AngularJS ng-cloak/ng-animate/ng-anchor CSS rules in <style> tags, ng-csp meta tag — these are injected by AngularJS framework initialization
page_fidelity.csrf_token_note: Meta tag <meta name='csrf-token' data-token='Kmz/DzjdHDnh'> present inside <body> — copied from a real Roblox page scrape to increase fidelity, but non-functional on the phishing domain
polish_comments_found: <!-- CSS Roblox – zachowane dla wyglądu --> (translation: 'CSS Roblox — kept for appearance')
meta_tags_cloned: description: Login to your Roblox account or sign up to create a new account.
keywords: free games, online games, building games, virtual worlds, free mmo, gaming cloud, physics engine
page_fidelity.copyright_text: 2022 Roblox Corporation. Roblox, the Roblox logo and Powering Imagination are among our registered and unregistered trademarks in the U.S. and other countries.
page_fidelity.fidelity_rating: very_high — 28 local CSS files scraped from real Roblox, AngularJS framework artifacts, csrf-token meta tag, full hreflang set, JSON-LD structured data, FunCaptcha references, real Roblox CDN CSS, complete navigation and footer cloned from legitimate site. Only giveaways are Polish HTML comments, copyright year frozen at 2022, navigation links pointing to index.html, and the obfuscated JS filename.

javascript_analysis.obfuscation_details: The main credential-harvesting script uses an obfuscated filename (oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js) and is placed in the css/ directory to masquerade as a stylesheet asset. The file content was not captured in the urlscan DOM snapshot.
javascript_analysis.cookie_access_note: No document.cookie access visible in the DOM snapshot HTML. The uncaptured JS file may contain cookie access.
javascript_analysis.anti_analysis_note: No anti-analysis techniques visible in inline code. A data-machine-id attribute on <head> tag (495b2758-5bb8-bf23-8b9a-7233b93d0fbf) may be a urlscan artifact or tracking identifier.

external_scripts.purpose: Arkose Labs FunCaptcha API — loaded from legitimate Roblox FunCaptcha endpoint. Included for visual fidelity but the empty callback (reportFunCaptchaLoaded(){}) means it has no functional purpose on this phishing page.
FunCaptcha initialization script — triggers empty callback, non-functional

local_scripts.purpose: Primary credential exfiltration script — placed in css/ directory to avoid detection. File not recovered in DOM snapshot.
suspicious_indicators: Gibberish filename to evade signature detection
Only JS file loaded — all credential harvesting logic concentrated here
Loaded at end of <body> to execute after DOM is ready

inline_script_analysis.content: Organization schema for Roblox with social media links
inline_script_analysis.purpose: SEO fidelity — copied from real roblox.com
Empty callback to prevent JS errors when FunCaptcha loads — captcha is decorative only

deceptive_onclick_handlers.deception: Button labeled 'Email Me a One-Time Code' actually submits the login form, harvesting any entered credentials
Button labeled 'Use Another Device' actually submits the login form, harvesting any entered credentials

javascript_analysis.notable_code: Three form submission vectors: (1) direct Log In button submit, (2) OTP button dispatches submit event on login form, (3) Cross-Device button dispatches submit event on login form. All three paths lead to credential harvesting. The actual exfiltration mechanism is in the unrecovered JS file css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js.

CSRF token meta tag implies server-side security validation

social_engineering.urgency_note: No urgency language detected — this phishing page relies on fidelity rather than urgency. The clone is so accurate that the user is unlikely to question its legitimacy.
social_engineering.target_demographic: Roblox players — primarily children and young adults

roblox_specific.navigation_links_behavior: Charts, Marketplace, Create, Robux, and all footer links point to index.html (the phishing site root) instead of real roblox.com subpages — a fidelity gap
real_roblox_links_preserved: https://www.roblox.com/ (Sign Up link in footer area)

cross_domain_links.references_to_roblox_com_us_note: No references to roblox-com.us found in the HTML/JS of this page. The link between the two domains is established only via CT log SAN overlap (Jan 2023 certificate), not via code-level references.

other_domain_references.context: Canonical URL, hreflang alternates, Sign Up link, Forgot Password link, JSON-LD structured data — legitimate Roblox references used for fidelity
One CSS file loaded from Roblox CDN (leanbase CSS)
FunCaptcha API scripts — legitimate Arkose Labs endpoint used by real Roblox
Referenced in JSON-LD structured data for Roblox logo image URL
Lato font loaded via NordVPN content script extension — this is a browser extension artifact from the urlscan scanning environment, not part of the phishing kit

takedown_analysis.redeployment_risk: high — only the GitHub Pages content was removed; DNS, domain registration (valid 9 more months), TLS certificate (valid 2+ more months), MX records, and SPF are all intact. Attacker can redeploy by pushing new content to a GitHub repo or re-pointing DNS to a different host.
takedown_analysis.takedown_effectiveness: partial — content removed (likely via GitHub abuse report removing the Pages repository) but domain/DNS/TLS/email infrastructure all remain active and ready for reuse. The Let's Encrypt cert was even renewed on Jan 19, 2026 (after the content was likely already down), suggesting automated renewal is still running.
recommended_actions: Report domain to OVH SAS registrar for suspension
Report to NASK (.pl registry) for domain takedown
Submit to Google Safe Browsing and Microsoft SmartScreen blocklists
Monitor for DNS A record changes indicating new hosting

Polish-language HTML comments indicate Polish-speaking kit author or operator

Three-vector form submission (direct submit + two deceptive buttons dispatching submit events)
Empty FunCaptcha callback pattern: decorative captcha loading for visual fidelity
Static GitHub Pages hosting pattern — common in low-sophistication phishing kits
data-machine-id attribute on <head> tag may be a kit fingerprint or urlscan artifact: 495b2758-5bb8-bf23-8b9a-7233b93d0fbf

kit_characteristics.sophistication: medium — high visual fidelity via automated asset scraping, but simple credential form with no server-side validation, no multi-step authentication flow, no session handling
kit_characteristics.likely_origin: Polish-speaking operator based on HTML comments
kit_characteristics.hosting_pattern: Static files on GitHub Pages — no backend server, exfiltration likely via third-party webhook or API endpoint in the JS file

urlscan_artifacts.nordvpn_extension_note: A NordVPN browser extension stylesheet (Lato font from Google Fonts) was injected into the DOM by the scanning browser — this is a urlscan environment artifact, not part of the phishing kit
urlscan_artifacts.dom_snapshot_limitations: The DOM snapshot captures the rendered HTML but did not include the content of css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js, which is the primary exfiltration script. Full behavioral analysis would require the JS file.

security_concepts: Credential harvesting form analysis: Identifying <form> elements, input fields, and submit handlers that capture usernames and passwords
Directory masquerading: Placing a JS exfiltration script in a css/ directory to evade casual inspection and some automated scanners

Deceptive UI elements: The OTP and Cross-Device buttons appear to offer alternative login methods but actually dispatch the credential-harvesting form submit — a social engineering technique that increases the chance of capturing partially-entered credentials
Decorative security controls: FunCaptcha loaded from legitimate Arkose Labs endpoints but with an empty callback — creates the appearance of bot protection without any actual functionality
CSRF token theater: A csrf-token meta tag copied from real Roblox adds apparent server-side security but is non-functional on a static phishing page
Asset scraping for fidelity: 28 CSS files with content-hash filenames were scraped from real roblox.com, achieving near-pixel-perfect visual cloning
Partial takedown ineffectiveness: Removing content without suspending the domain, revoking the certificate, or disabling DNS leaves infrastructure ready for rapid redeployment
DOM snapshot forensics: When live content is taken down, cached DOM snapshots from services like urlscan.io preserve evidence for analysis — critical for incident response and threat intel
talking_points: The phishing page achieves very high fidelity by scraping 28 CSS files, favicon, touch icons, and meta tags from real roblox.com, plus loading FunCaptcha scripts from legitimate Arkose Labs endpoints — a victim would see a page visually identical to the real Roblox login

Three credential harvesting vectors exist: the 'Log In' button submits the form directly, while the 'Email Me a One-Time Code' and 'Use Another Device' buttons use onclick handlers to dispatch a submit event on the same form — this means any button the user clicks harvests their credentials

The exfiltration script css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js uses two evasion techniques: (1) a gibberish filename to avoid signature matching, and (2) placement in the css/ directory to masquerade as a static asset
Polish-language HTML comments ('zachowane dla wyglądu' = 'kept for appearance', 'opcjonalny' = 'optional') reveal the kit author or operator is Polish-speaking, consistent with the .pl TLD choice

The page mixes real and fake links strategically: Sign Up and Forgot Password point to real roblox.com (building trust), while navigation links point to index.html (keeping the victim on the phishing domain)

The takedown was only partial — GitHub Pages content was removed but the domain (valid until Nov 2026), DNS, TLS cert (renewed Jan 2026, valid until Apr 2026), and email infrastructure all remain active, meaning redeployment requires only pushing new content or changing DNS A records
The urlscan DOM snapshot was essential for this analysis — without it, we would only have infrastructure data with no visibility into the actual phishing content or techniques used
notable_findings: THREE-VECTOR CREDENTIAL HARVESTING: All three user-facing buttons (Log In, Email OTP, Use Another Device) trigger the same form submission, maximizing the chance of capturing credentials regardless of which login method the victim attempts

DIRECTORY MASQUERADING: The sole JavaScript payload is named css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js — placing it in the css/ directory is a deliberate evasion technique to blend in with the 28 legitimate CSS files

DECORATIVE FUNCAPTCHA: FunCaptcha scripts load from real Arkose Labs endpoints but the callback is empty (function reportFunCaptchaLoaded() {}) — the captcha never actually renders, it exists solely to create the impression of bot protection in the page source

POLISH-SPEAKING OPERATOR: Two HTML comments in Polish ('zachowane dla wyglądu', 'opcjonalny') confirm the kit author/operator speaks Polish, providing an attribution data point that correlates with the .pl domain choice

MIXED REAL/FAKE LINKS: The Sign Up button, Forgot Password link, and sign-up prompt all link to real roblox.com, while navigation and footer links go to index.html — this hybrid approach builds trust while keeping the victim within the phishing domain

UNRECOVERED EXFILTRATION SCRIPT: The critical JS file (css/oefdspofrewoisfewfewfw02349.js) was not captured in the urlscan DOM snapshot, meaning we cannot determine the exact exfiltration endpoint (Discord webhook, Telegram bot, external server, etc.) — this is a gap in our analysis

FROZEN COPYRIGHT YEAR: Copyright text reads '2022 Roblox Corporation' — the page was scraped from roblox.com when the copyright said 2022, providing a loose timestamp for when the phishing kit's assets were originally collected

CERT RENEWAL AFTER TAKEDOWN: The Let's Encrypt certificate was renewed on Jan 19, 2026, likely after content was already removed — indicating automated renewal is running and the operator has not abandoned the infrastructure

security_concepts: ccTLD abuse: Using Polish .pl TLD to impersonate roblox.com via a hyphenated lookalike domain (roblox-com.pl)
GitHub Pages hosting abuse: Attacker leveraged free GitHub Pages hosting (185.199.108-111.153) to serve phishing content at zero cost with high uptime and built-in HTTPS
Let's Encrypt certificate abuse: Free DV certificate provides HTTPS padlock icon, demonstrating that padlock != trustworthy -- it only means encrypted transport, not site legitimacy
Domain registrar obfuscation: OVH SAS registrar with individual registrant type and Polish WHOIS redaction makes attacker attribution difficult
SPF record configuration: Attacker set up SPF (v=spf1 include:mx.ovh.com -all) and MX records, suggesting potential for credential-harvesting email campaigns or receiving exfiltrated data via email
TXT record redirect hint: The TXT record '1|www.roblox-com.pl' is an OVH-specific redirect indicator pointing bare domain to www subdomain
Certificate Transparency as OSINT: CT logs revealed the full timeline of the domain's phishing operations and linked it to a sibling domain roblox-com.us
Infrastructure commoditization: The entire phishing stack (OVH domain, GitHub Pages hosting, Let's Encrypt TLS) costs effectively nothing, lowering the barrier to entry for phishing campaigns
talking_points: The domain resolves to GitHub Pages IPs (185.199.108-111.153) with reverse DNS confirming cdn-185-199-110-153.github.com -- this means the attacker is hosting their phishing kit as a GitHub Pages site, abusing GitHub's free hosting infrastructure

Currently returning HTTP 404, indicating the phishing content has been taken down (likely via GitHub abuse report) but the domain infrastructure remains active with valid DNS, WHOIS, and a current TLS certificate

Certificate Transparency reveals two distinct operational periods: an initial campaign in January-February 2023 (4 certs across 3 weeks), then a ~2.5 year dormancy period, followed by reactivation in November 2025. This pattern suggests either a persistent threat actor reusing infrastructure or a domain that was re-registered

WHOIS shows domain was created 2025-11-04, but CT logs show certificates from January 2023 -- this means the domain was previously registered, expired, and was re-registered (potentially by the same or different operator)

A critical CT log finding: a January 2023 certificate for 'roblox-com.us' included 'roblox-com.pl' as a SAN, directly linking both phishing domains to the same operator running parallel ccTLD phishing campaigns (.pl and .us)

Missing ALL standard security headers (CSP, HSTS, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options) -- while GitHub Pages provides minimal headers, a legitimate site would have these, and their absence is consistent with a hastily deployed phishing page

The OVH nameservers (dns16.ovh.net, ns16.ovh.net) combined with OVH MX records show the attacker used a single provider (OVH) for domain registration, DNS, and email, then pointed the A records to GitHub Pages for free static hosting
Let's Encrypt R3 -> R13 issuer migration between the two operational periods reflects Let's Encrypt's own infrastructure changes, not an attacker action
notable_findings: CROSS-DOMAIN LINK: CT logs reveal roblox-com.us was issued a certificate that included roblox-com.pl as a SAN (2023-01-29), proving the same operator runs phishing campaigns across multiple ccTLDs

TWO-PHASE OPERATION: The domain shows a Jan-Feb 2023 campaign phase (ZeroSSL + Let's Encrypt R3 certs), a ~2.5 year gap, then reactivation Nov 2025 (Let's Encrypt R13) -- the WHOIS creation date of 2025-11-04 confirms re-registration

CURRENTLY 404: Despite having valid DNS, active WHOIS, and a current TLS cert (valid until April 2026), the site returns a GitHub Pages 404, suggesting recent takedown of the phishing content but persistence of the supporting infrastructure

FULL EMAIL INFRASTRUCTURE: MX records pointing to OVH mail servers plus SPF records suggest the attacker configured email capability, possibly for receiving stolen credentials or sending phishing lures from the lookalike domain
ZERO-COST ATTACK STACK: Domain (~$5/year via OVH), hosting (free GitHub Pages), TLS (free Let's Encrypt), email (free OVH MX) -- total cost under $10/year for a credible phishing operation

ANYCAST IP: ipinfo.io confirms the GitHub Pages IPs are anycast, meaning the phishing content was served from edge locations worldwide for low latency -- ironically better infrastructure than many legitimate sites
VARNISH/FASTLY CACHING: The x-served-by and via headers show Fastly/Varnish CDN caching in front of GitHub Pages, giving the phishing site enterprise-grade performance and DDoS protection for free
